blocks.text: Having satisfied ourselves that the ordinary rules of indices may be applied to D, now we may prove that the rules of factorisation apply also.
Taking the expression DÂ² - 12D + 32, we can easily show that it can be written in the factor form (D - 4)(D - 8):

This shows how the expression can be resolved into its factors.

blocks.text: These properties make D of great usefulness in the solution of certain types of differential equations.

blocks.text: and the solution of equation (1) may be found by this artifact. Many differential equations occurring in electrical theory may be solved in a very simple manner under the treatment of D as a `quasi-algebraic operator'; before proceeding to these, however, we must enunciate the following theorems.
